div1.p: Subject. Reasons why I cannot recommend James Rob't Spurgeon Esq., Secretary of this Legation for the Vice Consul Generalship of this Consulate General.
No. 69. Consular. Legation of the United States, Monrovia Liberia; May 15, 1901.
Hon. David J. Hill, Assistant Secretary of State, Washington.

Sir: I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt May 13, 1901, of your No. 33, Consular, of April 10, 1901, informing me that "the Department greatly prefers Mr. Spurgeon's appointment, to the position of Vice Consul General, rather than that of a foreigner."
In reply, I have to say I regret exceedingly much to have to give my reasons for withholding my indorsement and recommendation of

of Mr. Spurgeon for the Vice Consul Generalship; especially so, inasmuch as he has just, a few days since, sailed for America, and is not here to see my reply; in order, if he so desires to file his answer. However, as he sailed by a very slow schedule, it may be possible, that this dispatch may be dispatched by a fast German steamer; and may thereby, reach Wasington before he does, in order, that he may be shown my objections &c, while in Washington.
First. I refer you to my No. 67, Consular, of April 15, 1901.
Second, My immediate official association with Mr. SPurgeon, as Secretary of the Legation, for the last three years, has convinced me

me (1) of his very careless and neglectful disposition; (2) of his insubordinate, presumption and selfwellness. Notwithstanding, your No. 32, Consular, of March 12, 1901, and my No. 67, Consular, of April 15, 1901, in reply; in evidnece of my assertion of his carelessness, insubordinale and presumptive disposition I will enclose herewith, a copy of an undated, unnumbered and recorded dispatch prepared by the Secretary of the Legation the contents of which I had no knowledge, as he had not, at that time, asked my approval, as to what time he could leave the Legation; until I discovered it in the Despatch Book, the day after it was recorded, admonished him for

for such persistency and demanded that it be cancelled and not dispatched; and in lieu thereof I wrote and dispatched my No. 125, Diplomatic of May 10, 1901. As asserted in my No. 67, Consular of April 15, 1901, Mr. Spurgeon never asks my consent nor advice, relative to anythinng he desires to do, in connection with the duties of the Legation; but when he has decided to do; as in the case of his determination to leave the Legation and the city April 9, 1901; he simply informs me, at the last moment, as he did in this instant come to my bedside Monday afternoon, April 8, 1901, and told me he had previously arranged to spend two or

or three weeks, with friends in the interior, before he sailed for America; and would therefore, leave on Tuesday morning April 9, 1901. I was quit sick and helpless, at the time; had no power, or authority, by which I could restrain him, and was therefore, forced to silently, acquiesce.

Third. For me to have indorced or recommended Mr. Spurgeon for the Vice Consul Generalship, would have conveyed to the Department, my indorcement and recomendation of Mr. Spurgeon for his reappointment as Secretary of this Legation for another term of honorable service.
And as my personal and official experiences with

with him, do not warrant nor justify me in indorsing or recommending him for the Vice Consul Generalship, I could not honestly and conscientiously indorse nor recommend him for reappointment as Secretary of this Legation. I have to say, however, that I will acquiesce in whatever may be the pleasure of the Department, toching this very important matter.
Inclosures. Nos. 1, 2, and 3.
Copy.
Honorable John Hay, Secretary of State, Washington.
Subject. James Robt Spurgeon, U.S. Secy of Leg. at Monrovia on leave of absence to visit the United States departs from his Port of duty.
Copy. 3
Hoorable John Hay, Secretary of State, Washington.

Sir: I have the honor to advise you that in keeping with your dispatch T/J of Nov. 12, 1900 (in reply to my dispatch of Oct, 11, 1900) granting me a leave of absence with permission to visit the United States for sixty days, having obtained the approval of the Minister in charge of this Legation of my departure from Liberia after the March Quarter, I do now this day of May 1901 take passage on board the S. S. "Axem," for New York via
via of Liverpool.
I have the honor to remain, Sir, Your obedient servant, James Rob't Surgeon.
Inclosure No. 1.
Affidavit
British Vice-Consulate Monrovia Liberia 15th May 1901

Personally appeared before me, William Arthur Ring, British Vice-Consul for the Republic of Liberia. Jusua Vaughen, who being duly sworn, deposeth and saith that he was born in Malvern, Arkansas, United States of America, Dec. 25th 1880, that he has been in the employment of the United States Legation Monrovia Liberia since Dec 26th 1898, that he has been employed as messenger of said Legation from Jan. 1st 1900 to the present time
That the official hours of said Legation are from ten o'clock A.M. to four o'clock P.M.
That James Robert Spurgeon Secretary

Secretary of the said Legation, seldom reaches the Legation before eleven to to half past eleven o'clock A.M., not infrequently twelve o'clock noon before he arrived. That the said James Robert Spurgeon usually leaves the Legation between half past one and two o'clock P.M. sometimes he returned about ten minutes before four o'clock P.M. but more frequently not before the following day.

That during the very severe illness of Minister Smith; March 30th to April 15th 1901, James Robert Spurgeon the Secretary of the Legation did on the 9th day of April (while the Minister was entirely helpless and could not leave his bedroom) leave the Legation and the city for a cleasure trip in the country, not returning to the Legation until the afternoon of April 19th 1901.
That during his absence and while the Minister was helpless, the United

United States schooner "Arthur B. Smith" of New York, A. J. Stanley Master, put in this port. The minister being sick and not able to go down to the office to prepare the proper papers to give the Captain upon delivery of the ship's papers; had him a Messenger to bring the truck containing blank forms to the Minister's bedside and there hold up one form after another until the Minister had selected such as he desired for the occasion and then placed them near his bedside until the Captain arrived. The minister in an infeebled condition then went into the parlor of the Legation, there met the Captain and received his papers.
That the Secretary of the Legation does not allow me, as a messenger, to put his mail nor deliver it to him upon arrival
Sworn to and subscribed before me this 15th day of May 1901 Joshua Vaughn. Messenger United States Legation Monrovia, Liberia Sworn
Sworn by Joshua Vaughan Gratis at Monrovia on this fifteenth day of May 1901, before me W. A. Ring British Vice Consul
Affidavits
British Vice Consulate Monrovia, Liberia 15th May 1901

Personally appeared before me, William Arthur Ring, British Vice-Consul for the Republic of Liberia. Sarah A. Carmichael, a reputable person, who being duly sworn deposeth and saith that she was born in the States of Alabama, United States of America, that she is forty four years of age, has been in the employment of the United States' Legation since the 10th of November 1898, first as a cook and since the 23rd of March 1900 as housekeeper.
That she is personally acquainted with James Robert Spurgeon, the Secretary of that Legation, that he seldom reaches the Legation before eleven to half past eleven o'clock A.M. and usually
usually leaves between half past one and two o'clock P.M. Sometimes he returns just before the closing of business hours but frequently not before the following day.

That during the very severe and helpless illness of Minister Smith 30th of March to April 15th 1901, the Secretary of the Legation did leave the Legation and the city on Tuesday morning APril 9th and did not return to the Legation until Friday afternoon April 19th 1901
Sworn to and subscribed before me this 15th day of May 1901
Sarah A. Carmichael her X mark Housekeeper United States Legation Monrovia Liberia
Witness Joshua Vaugh. Messenger united States Legation andG. H. Green Sworn
Sworn by Sarah A. Carmichael Grate at Monrovia on this fifteenth day of May 1901, before me W. A. Ring British Vice-Consul
